title: 104_s1886
content: Private foundations are not required to include certain education grants and loans in their taxable expenditures. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection on qualified employer-related grant programs, which must be objective and nondiscriminatory. These programs cannot be used for recruiting or retaining employees. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection on qualified employer-related grant programs. These programs must be objective and nondiscriminatory, cannot be used for recruiting or retaining employees, and must select grantees through a committee that does not have conflicts of interest. Grantees must meet minimum standards for admission to an educational institution. The new subsection on qualified employer-related grant programs in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires institutions to select grantees based on objective criteria unrelated to employment or business interests. Grants cannot be denied based on the performance of employees who are grantees. The new subsection on qualified employer-related grant programs in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 sets criteria for grantees, prohibits denial based on employee performance, and excludes certain individuals from eligibility. The new subsection in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 establishes criteria for grantees in employer-related grant programs, excluding disqualified persons and highly compensated employees or their family members. The new subsection in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 sets criteria for grantees in employer-related grant programs, excluding disqualified persons and giving preference to employees or their family members. Highly compensated employees are defined as per section 414(q)(1). The amendments made by this section apply to grants or loans made after the date of enactment of this Act.
